thread.title: Shannon Noll 'escorted off stage by police'
thread.title_full: Shannon Noll 'escorted off stage by police' | Daily Mail Online

author: Max Margan For Daily Mail Australia
title: Shannon Noll 'escorted off stage by police'
text:
Shannon Noll was light-heartedly dragged off stage by police just hours after he was a no-show at court over an alleged scuffle at an Adelaide strip club.
The former Australian Idol star, 41, was finishing up his set at Sandstone Point in Queensland on Saturday with a performance of his famous cover What About Me.
As the hit song drew to a close, two uniformed officers escorted Noll off stage and led him away from thousands of adoring fans.
Shannon Noll was a no-show at court over an alleged scuffle at an Adelaide strip club, the singer was light-heartedly dragged off stage by police
Two uniformed officers escorted Noll off stage and led him away from thousands of adoring fans
But once out of the crowd's view, the officers both flashed broad smiles and each gave Noll a high-five.
'There's not much I can say about that one. Luckily this one was just a joke though,' the singer could be heard saying in a video uploaded to his Facebook page.
Noll was seemingly poking fun at the alleged incident at the Crazy Horse Revue strip club last month when he was accused of assaulting a bouncer.
On Friday, reporters waited outside Adelaide Magistrates Court for Noll to appear in relation to the incident but he did not show.
Noll was seemingly poking fun at the alleged incident at the Crazy Horse Revue strip club last month when he was accused of assaulting a bouncer
Noll was excused from a scheduled court appearance over the alleged scuffle with security guards
'Mr Noll is not present,' defence lawyer Andrew Ey told the court.
'Obviously he resides and works interstate. I ask your honour to excuse his non-attendance today.'
Magistrate Rodney Oates was obliging but said Noll must appear in person on the next occasion, a pre-trail conference in April.
'I will excuse his non-attendance today but he needs to be here next time,' Mr Oates said.
Reporters waited outside Adelaide Magistrates Court for Noll to appear on Friday but he did not show
Magistrate Rodney Oates was obliging but said Noll must appear in person on the next occasion, a pre-trail conference in April
